channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: When It Comes to Russia, Trump Navigates Conflicting Goals
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to court President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are rife with contradictions about stability and displays of American power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Alaska last August. Mr. Trump’s focus on strength has magnified tensions with Russia in regions like Latin America, where Mr. Putin has sought to extend his influence

item.title: During Maduro Raid in Venezuela, a Close Call for Helicopters and Trump’s Plan
item.description: As a damaged U.S. helicopter struggled to stay aloft over Venezuela’s capital, the success of the entire operation hung in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Hoisting Russian Flags, ‘Shadow Fleet’ Edges Into the Light
item.description: The Marinera, which was seized by the U.S., isn’t the only ship from the “shadow fleet” of oil tankers to switch lately to a Russian identity, seeking protection.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vesa Moilanen/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Eagle S, an oil tanker, last January after Finnish commandos commandeered it over suspicions that it had deliberately cut vital undersea cables. The authorities said the ship appeared to belong to Russia’s shadow fleet.

item.title: Lawmakers Split After Classified Briefings on Venezuela
item.description: Republicans praised what they characterized as a narrow and well-executed plan, while Democrats expressed alarm, warning that the mission was vaguely defined.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at the Capitol on Wednesday after a Senate briefing on operations in Venezuela.

item.title: Renee Good, Victim in Minneapolis ICE Shooting, Remembered for Her Kindness
item.description: Renee Good, 37, a resident of Minneapolis, was mourned on Wednesday as a cherished member of the community.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners placing flowers at a makeshift memorial near the site in Minneapolis where Renee Nicole Good, 37, was shot and killed in her vehicle.

item.title: The ICE Shooting Came During an Operation Focused on Somali Immigrants
item.description: Federal immigration officials have stepped up enforcement activity in Minnesota amid a fraud scandal there that includes many people of Somali origin.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:description: Federal officers surround Gregory Bovino, center, a senior Border Patrol official, at the site in Minneapolis where a federal immigration officer fatally shot a woman on Wednesday.

item.title: Horns, Whistles and Then Gunfire on a Minneapolis Street
item.description: A man opened his door to discover a tableau of deadly violence after a federal agent fatally shot a woman.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: A man yelling at federal officers gathered near a vehicle after its driver was fatally shot in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Says He Wants Congress to Stop Wall St. From Buying Single-Family Houses
item.description: The president said he wanted Congress to stop the purchases by big investors, which have driven up rents and set obstacles for first-time buyers in some markets.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: Blackstone, the huge private equity firm, is among the largest operator of single-family home rentals that could be affected by the president’s demand.

item.title: Trump Pulls Out of Global Climate Treaty
item.description: The action could make it more difficult for a future administration to rejoin the Paris climate accord, the agreement among most nations to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York last year.

item.title: Trump Withdraws the U.S. From More International Organizations
item.description: The executive order the president signed Wednesday follows a broader vision of American foreign policy that shuns coalition building and the consensus of nations.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the United Nations General Assembly last year. The U.N. did not immediately comment on the United States’ severing relationships with some of its organizations.

item.title: Justice Dept. Staff Fear Turmoil Diverts Them From Potential Threats
item.description: Rank-and-file prosecutors and agents have expressed serious concern that a hobbled work force hurts the government’s ability to identify and stop terrorist plots, cyberattacks, mass violence and fraud.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Across the Justice Department, rank-and-file workers have expressed deep concern that a denigrated, distracted and depleted work force undercuts the government’s ability to identify and stop terrorist plots, cyberattacks, mass violence and fraud, putting the country in a weaker position.

item.title: New Novels to Read This Year
item.description: Tayari Jones, Ann Patchett, George Saunders and Veronica Roth return with new novels; Jennette McCurdy makes her fiction debut; and more.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Salazar and Laura Thompson

item.title: New Nonfiction Books to Read This Year
item.description: Memoirs by Sylvester Stallone and the founder of Barstool Sports; essays from celebrated novelists Jesmyn Ward and Jayne Anne Phillips; and more.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Salazar and Laura Thompson

item.title: Steny Hoyer, Longest-Serving House Democrat, to Retire From Congress
item.description: The Maryland congressman, who served as one of his party’s top leaders, plans to depart after nearly half a century in Congress, as his party looks toward generational change.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Why Russian Tourists Are Flocking to Southern China’s Beaches
item.description: Russians find a refuge on the beaches of Sanya from sanctions and “sideways looks,” toasting the New Year beside a Chinese nuclear submarine base.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

item.title: Nick Reiner’s Lawyer, Alan Jackson, Removes Himself From Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who is charged with killing his parents, will now be represented by a public defender. His arraignment has been rescheduled for next month.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Nick Reiner was charged with two counts of first-degree murder. If he is convicted, he could face a life sentence without parole or the death penalty.

item.title: As Charlie Kirk’s Turning Point Pushes Into High Schools, Dissension Follows
item.description: Since Mr. Kirk’s death, chapters of his organization’s affiliate for teenagers have more than doubled in number, aided by politicians who have said they won’t tolerate opposition.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Lexi Parra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Club America members from Stratford High School in Houston found themselves caught between concerned parents on the left and Texas’ most powerful politicians on the right.

item.title: University to Pay $500,000 to Professor It Fired Over Charlie Kirk Post
item.description: Austin Peay State University in Tennessee also reinstated Darren Michael, a tenured acting professor whose post about Mr. Kirk’s killing inflamed conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Austin Peay, based in Clarksville, Tenn., backtracked on firing the professor less than two weeks later, placing him on a paid suspension.

item.title: Texas A&M Warns Professor Not to Teach Plato Because of Gender Rules
item.description: The university is reviewing courses under new rules restricting teaching about race and gender. Administrators told a philosophy professor to cut some lessons on Plato to comply.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Texas A&M University campus in College Station.

item.title: Protests Spread in Iran, and Crackdowns Escalate
item.description: Bazaars were shuttered and demonstrators met with violence from security forces amid rising anger about the country’s dire economic situation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from social media shows Iranian security forces using tear gas to disperse protesters at the Tehran bazaar on Tuesday.

item.title: Can Timothée Chalamet Break This Oscar Curse?
item.description: The best actor Oscar almost never goes to young men, though the 30-year-old has his best chance yet with “Marty Supreme.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: 2026 SAG Actor Award Nominations List: ‘One Battle’ and ‘Sinners’ Lead
item.description: Timothée Chalamet and Ariana Grande also scored nods. Cynthia Erivo and the stars of “Jay Kelly” were left out.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: How Machado Lost Her Chance to Lead Venezuela
item.description: The opposition leader’s uncompromising style explains her political rise. But will that brand of politics work as well when it comes to running a country?
item.dc:creator: Francisco Rodríguez

item.title: Trump Is About to Lose Control of the Economy
item.description: Will anyone be in charge?
item.dc:creator: Jason Furman
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Spencer Pratt, Reality TV Star, Runs for Mayor of Los Angeles
item.description: The star of “The Hills,” whose house burned in the Palisades fire, has used his social media profile to hammer Mayor Karen Bass and other California Democrats over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: Spencer Pratt, whose home in Pacific Palisades was burned in last January's wildfire, announced his candidacy for mayor of Los Angeles on Wednesday.

item.title: Philip Yancey, Prominent Christian Author, Admits to Extramarital Affair
item.description: He said he would retire from writing and public speaking.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: St. Petersburg Times/Zuma Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Philip Yancey has been married to his wife, Janet, for 55 years.

item.title: Glenn Hall, Pathbreaking All-Star Hockey Goalie, Dies at 94
item.description: Known as “Mr. Goalie,” he created the so-called butterfly style and played in a record 502 consecutive games, without wearing a mask. He received 300 stitches.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:description: Goalie Glenn Hall of the Chicago Blackhawks in 1959.
